gr.interamerican.bo2.arch
Interface Worker

All Known Subinterfaces:
DataCommand, EntitiesQuery<P>, FastPoReader<K,P>, LoginOperation<A>, Operation, PersistenceWorker<PO>, Query, Question<A>, Rule
public interface Worker

Worker is the basic interface for any runtime independent operation.
A Worker is a class that requires runtime dependent resources to complete its tasks. It will acquire these resources by the runtime layer abstraction that is represented by a Provider. Workers must never destroy or modify the resources that are provided by a provider. The provider is responsible for the life cycle of any resource it provides.
For example, a worker that receives a database connection by his provider should never close or destroy this connection.
Typical use of a worker w is like this:
w.init(provider);
w.open();
//do something with w here
w.close();

Method Summary
 void close()
          Worker cleanup.
 Provider getProvider()
          Gets a reference to this worker's parent Provider.
 void init(Provider parent)
          Introduces the runtime context (environment) to the worker.
 void open()
          Prepares the worker.
 

Method Detail

open

void open()
          throws DataException
Prepares the worker. Creation or initialization of any attribute that requires runtime dependent resources takes place here.

Throws:
DataException - When the preparation of the worker fails.

close

void close()
           throws DataException
Worker cleanup. Cleanup of any resources that were created by the worker. These resources are created by the open() method. Resources provided by the parent provider in the init(Provider p) method belong to the parent and their state should not be modified by the worker.

Throws:
DataException - When the cleanup fails.

init

void init(Provider parent)
          throws InitializationException
Introduces the runtime context (environment) to the worker. The parent provides the runtime context. The runtime context can be anything that facilitates access to any back-end system (Databases, Files, Application Server etc).
Different implementations of Worker, will require from their parent provider resources of different types. Sub-interfaces of Provider can provide resources of any type. The implementations of worker must get the specific sub-type of Provider by their parent by calling the method parent.getProvider(subclass) where subclass is the sub-interface of Provider that is required.

Parameters:
parent - The runtime provider
Throws:
InitializationException - When the parent fails to provide the resources required by the worker.

getProvider

Provider getProvider()
Gets a reference to this worker's parent Provider.

Returns:
Returns a reference to the Worker's parent Provider.
